scenario:
S&P Global is a $162 billion market cap business that provides critical credit ratings and financial data to support the functioning of capital markets. Its shares have climbed 86% in the past five years. 

In 2024, the business increased revenue 14% year over year to $14.2 billion, driven by a 31% sales jump in the Ratings segment. Revenue rose 6% in the Market Intelligence division, the biggest money maker. The company has reported five straight years of double-digit revenue growth since 2019.

S&P Global's adjusted operating margin was 49% last year, and executives believe it will be similar in 2025. The company has a low capital expenditure, generating lots of free cash flow to fund dividends and share buybacks.

The business has an economic moat due to a network effect, where large corporations rely on S&P Global's ratings for their debt issuance. This makes it difficult for new entrants to tap into the industry.

The current price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 42.6 is 10% higher than the trailing-10-year average. Analyst estimates suggest the company's earnings per share (EPS) will grow at a compound annual rate of 11% between 2024 and 2027.

The stock may not be a buy below $550, but it could be if the valuation becomes more compelling. The company's competitively advantaged business registers healthy growth and sizable profits, but the current valuation may not justify outperforming the S&P 500 over the next five years.
